(2024-02-14)

  • Derivative is the amount of change in a target object caused by a variable’s change.

  • A row a matrix consists of the coefficient of each term in a linear equation. And based on the “sum rule” of derivative ($(f+g)’=f’+g’$), the derivative of the linear equation w.r.t. a variable is the summation of the derivative of each element in the row w.r.t. the variable.

Source video: Derivative of a Matrix : Data Science Basics - ritvikmath

Matrix ùêÄ() stands for a linear transformation (function). And only the derivative of a function (ùêÄùê±) makes sense.

  • Matrix is a representation of linear systems.

$$ \begin{aligned} f(x) &= ùêÄùê± \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x‚ÇÅ \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} x‚ÇÅ + 2 x‚ÇÇ \\ 3x‚ÇÅ + 4x‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} ‚áí \begin{bmatrix} f‚ÇÅ(x‚ÇÅ,x‚ÇÇ) \\ f‚ÇÇ(x‚ÇÅ,x‚ÇÇ) \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned} $$

$$ \frac{dùêÄùê±}{dùê±} = \begin{bmatrix} ‚àÇf‚ÇÅ/‚àÇx‚ÇÅ & ‚àÇf‚ÇÅ/‚àÇx‚ÇÇ \\ ‚àÇf‚ÇÇ/‚àÇx‚ÇÅ & ‚àÇf‚ÇÇ/‚àÇx‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix} $$

The derivative of the linear transformation ùêÄùê± w.r.t. x is A. It analog to single-variable function.

A matrix $A$ is a “scalar”. More concretely, it’s a collection of scalars in a box.

Therefore, the derivative of A means the derivative of a constant, which would be 0. So, it doesn’t make any sense.

Thereby, we are not calculating the derivative of a matrix, but the derivative of a linear transformation ùêÄùê± w.r.t. ùê±.

$$ \begin{aligned} ùê±·µÄùêÄùê± &= \begin{bmatrix} x‚ÇÅ & x‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ & a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ \\ a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅ & a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x‚ÇÅ \\ x‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} x‚ÇÅ & x‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅx‚ÇÅ+ a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇx‚ÇÇ \\ a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅx‚ÇÅ + a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇx‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} \\ &= a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅx‚ÇÅ¬≤+ a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇx‚ÇÅx‚ÇÇ + a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅx‚ÇÅx‚ÇÇ + a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇx‚ÇÇ¬≤ ‚áí f(x‚ÇÅ,x‚ÇÇ) \end{aligned} $$

Consider ùêÄ is a symmetric matrix, so a‚ÇÇ = a‚ÇÉ. Then, $ùê±·µÄùêÄùê± = a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅx‚ÇÅ¬≤+ a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇx‚ÇÅx‚ÇÇ + a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅx‚ÇÅx‚ÇÇ + a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇx‚ÇÇ¬≤ = f(x‚ÇÅ,x‚ÇÇ)$

The derivative of the linear transformation ùê±·µÄùêÄùê±:

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{dùê±·µÄùêÄùê±}{dùê±} &= \begin{bmatrix} ‚àÇf/‚àÇx‚ÇÅ \\ ‚àÇf/‚àÇx‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} 2a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅx‚ÇÅ+2a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇx‚ÇÇ \\ 2a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇx‚ÇÇ + 2a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇx‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} \\ &= 2 \begin{bmatrix} a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ & a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ \\ a‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ & a‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x‚ÇÅ \\ x‚ÇÇ \end{bmatrix} \\ &= 2ùêÄùê± \end{aligned} $$

Source article: The derivative matrix - Math Insight

  1. A matrix ùêÄ contains elements that are functions of a scalar x.

    • Derivative of ùêü w.r.t. each coordinate axis.
    • $\frac{df}{dùê±} = [ \frac{‚àÇf}{‚àÇx‚ÇÅ}\ \frac{‚àÇf}{‚àÇx‚ÇÇ}\ ‚ãØ \ \frac{‚àÇf}{‚àÇx‚Çô} ]$

  3. A matrix ùêÄ contains elements that are functions of a vector ùê±.

    • $ùêÄ(ùê±) = ùêü(ùê±) = (f_1(ùê±),\ f_2(ùê±),\ …, f_m(ùê±)) = \begin{bmatrix} f_1(ùê±) \\ f_2(ùê±) \\ ‚ãÆ \\ f_m(ùê±) \end{bmatrix}$

    • The $\frac{dùêÄ}{dùê±}$ is a matrix with the size of mxn:

      $$ \frac{dùêÄ}{dùê±} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{f_1}{x_1} & \frac{f_1}{x_2} & ‚ãØ & \frac{f_1}{x‚Çô} \\ \frac{f_2}{x_1} & \frac{f_2}{x_2} & ‚ãØ & \frac{f_2}{x‚Çô} \\ ‚ãÆ & ‚ãÆ & ‚ãÆ & ‚ãÆ \\ \frac{f_m}{x_1} & \frac{f_m}{x_2} & ‚ãØ & \frac{f_m}{x‚Çô} \\ \end{bmatrix} $$

Matrix derivative

(2023-02-12)

Matrix derivatie is in terms of the whole matrix, instead of each element. Whereas partial derivatives of a matrix

Given a matrix $[^{a\ b}_{d\ c}]$,the derivative of its inverse matrix $\frac{1}{ac-bd}[^{\ c\ -b}_{-d\ a}]$ w.r.t. the original matrix is the “coefficient” in their relation:

$$ \underbrace{ \begin{bmatrix} c & -b \\ -d & a \end{bmatrix} \frac{1}{ac-bd} \begin{bmatrix} c & -b \\ -d & a \end{bmatrix} }_{\text{Coefficient}} \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ d & c \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} c & -b \\ -d & a \end{bmatrix} $$

  • This transformation can be understood as that the original matrix first times its inverse $\frac{1}{ac-bd}[^{\ c\ -b}_{-d\ a}]$ to become the identity matrix $[^{1\ 0}_{0\ 1}]$, which gets multiplied by $[^{\ c\ -b}_{-d\ a}]$ to yield the inverse matrix.

    Therefore, the coefficient is:

    $$ \frac{1}{ac-bd} \begin{bmatrix} c & -b \\ -d & a \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} c & -b \\ -d & a \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{ac-bd} \begin{bmatrix} c¬≤ + bd & -bc-ab \\ -cd-ad & bd+a¬≤\end{bmatrix} $$

    In this case, is the optimizing objective the whole matrix $[^{a\ b}_{d\ c}]$, with its coefficient serving as the gradient?

  • perplexity

On the other hand, the partial derivatives of the inverse matrix $\frac{1}{ac-bd}[^{\ c\ -b}_{-d\ a}]$ with respect to each element a, b, c, d can be conceptualized as:

how does changes in the 4 “variables” $a,\ b,\ c,\ d$ affect the matrix $\frac{1}{ac-bd}[^{\ c\ -b}_{-d\ a}]$

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{ ‚àÇ\frac{1}{ac-bd} \begin{bmatrix} c & -b \\ -d & a \end{bmatrix}}{‚àÇa} &= \begin{bmatrix} \frac{‚àÇ}{‚àÇa} (\frac{c}{ac-bd} ) & \frac{‚àÇ}{‚àÇa} (\frac{-b}{ac-bd}) \\ \frac{‚àÇ}{‚àÇa} (\frac{-d}{ac-bd}) & \frac{‚àÇ}{‚àÇa} (\frac{a}{ac-bd} ) \\ \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} \frac{-c¬≤}{(ac-bd)¬≤} & \frac{bc}{(ac-bd)¬≤} \\ \frac{dc}{(ac-bd)¬≤} & \frac{-bd}{(ac-bd)¬≤} \\ \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned} $$

The total change of the matrix magnitude caused by moving $a$ by one unit would be:

$$\frac{‚àÇ (\frac{1}{ac-bd} [^{\ c\ -b}_{-d\ a}] )}{‚àÇa} = \frac{-c¬≤ + bc + dc - bd}{(ac-bd)¬≤} $$

  • Particularly, with this derivative, $a$ can be optimized via gradient descent.

Similarly, the partial derivatives of the matrix w.r.t. $b,\ c,\ d$ are:

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{‚àÇ (\frac{1}{ac-bd} [^{\ c\ -b}_{-d\ a}] )}{‚àÇb} &= \frac{cd-ac-d¬≤+ad}{(ac-bd)¬≤} \\ \frac{‚àÇ (\frac{1}{ac-bd} [^{\ c\ -b}_{-d\ a}] )}{‚àÇc} &= \frac{-bd+ba+da-a¬≤}{(ac-bd)¬≤} \\ \frac{‚àÇ (\frac{1}{ac-bd} [^{\ c\ -b}_{-d\ a}] )}{‚àÇd} &= \frac{cb-b¬≤-ac+ab}{(ac-bd)¬≤} \\ \end{aligned} $$

    The scale factor is the ratio between a target dimension and a source dimension. Thus, by multiplying those factors, the source space will be scaled to the target space.

item.description:
Source video: 21. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors - Gilbert Strang - MIT OpenCourseWare

(2023-11-06) The 1st-time recitation note. Haven’t re-check.

Out direction same as in

Matrix multiply vector acting like MLP, where all current dimensions are combined in different weights to produce each dimension in another space.

$$ ùêÄ ùêó \\ \begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ y_3 \end{bmatrix} = ùêÄ \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} $$

  1. Matrix ùêÄ is like a function that takes as input ùêó and output ùêÄùêó.
  2. Typically, ùêÄùêó points in different direction from the input ùêó.
  3. Eigenvectors are those ùêó make ùêÄùêó parallels to ùêó.
  4. Parallel means scaling: ùêÄùêó = Œªùêó, where the multiplier Œª is eigenvalue.

Given a matrix ùêÄ, how to solve its eigenvalues Œª and eigenvectors ùêó?

  • If Œª = 0, ùêó solved from ùêÄùêó = 0 by elimination is ùüé, which is useless.

Some hints can be found through the following examples

Projection matrix

Given a projection matrix ùêè, a 3D vector is projected on to a plane.

  1. Eigenvectors ùêó should parallel to the projected vectors ùêèùêó. So the vectors located in the plane all are eigenvectors, as $ùêèùêó=ùêó$, with Œª=1.

  2. Vectors perpendicular to the plane statisfy: $ùêèùêó=0$, i.e., Œª=0.

  3. Those two sets of eigenvectors are perpendicular.

Permutation matrix

Given the 2D permutation matrix $ùêÄ=[^{0 \ 1}_{1 \ 0}]$, which vector can make ùêÄùêó=ùêó, i.e., identical after permutation.

  1. ùêó = $[^1_1]$, with Œª=1.

  2. As ùêÄ is a 2D matrix, there should be 2 eigenvalues. Which vector can statisfy Œª=-1 ?

    ùêó = $[^{-1}_1]$

  3. The 2 sets of eigenvectors ùêó are perpendicular as well.

  4. Fact: The sum of eigenvalues equals to the sum of elements on diagonal of ùêÄ.

    Here, there is 1 + (-1) = 0 + 0.

How to solve Œª, ùêó

Trick: Rearrange to ùêÄùêó - Œªùêó = 0.

If there is $(ùêÄ - Œªùêà)ùêó = 0$ and ùêó, a non-zero vector, becomes 0 after multiplied by (ùêÄ - Œªùêà), the (ùêÄ - Œªùêà) must be sigular: determinant is 0.

The formula $ùêÄ - Œªùêà = 0$ doesn’t include ùêó, so eigenvalues Œª can be solved first, as in the example below.

Plus multiple identity

Given a matrix ùêÄ = $[^{3 \ 1}_{1 \ 3}]$, to calculate Œª, solve:

$$ \begin{aligned} | ùêÄ - Œªùêà | = 0 \\ \begin{bmatrix} 3-Œª & 1 \\ 1 & 3-Œª \end{bmatrix} = 0 \\ (3-Œª)^2 -1 = 0 \\ Œª^2 - 6Œª + 8 = 0 \\ (Œª-4)(Œª-2) = 0 \end{aligned} $$

Two roots: Œª‚ÇÅ=4, Œª‚ÇÇ=2. Then solve the 2 sets of eigenvectors.

  1. For Œª‚ÇÅ=4,

    $$ \begin{aligned} (ùêÄ - Œªùêà)ùêó = 0 \\ \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{bmatrix} ùêó = 0 \\ \end{aligned} $$

    By letting the free variable to 1, ùêó can be solved as $[^1_1]$.

    Hence, one of eigenvectors is $[^1_1]$

  2. For Œª‚ÇÇ=2,

    $$ \begin{aligned} (ùêÄ - Œªùêà)ùêó = 0 \\ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} ùêó = 0 \\ \end{aligned} $$

    Hence, one of eigenvectors is $[^{-1}_1]$

The sum of the two eigenvalues is the trace of ùêÄ, and their product is the determinant of ùêÄ.

Comparing the matrix $[^{3 \ 1}_{1 \ 3}]$ and the permutation matrix $[^{0 \ 1}_{1 \ 0}]$, there is:

A $[^{3 \ 1}_{1 \ 3}]$ $[^{0 \ 1}_{1 \ 0}]$
Œª 4 and 2 1 and -1
ùêó $[^1_1]$ and $[^{-1}_1]$ $[^1_1]$ and $[^{-1}_1]$

If $ùêÄùêó =Œªùêó$, then $(ùêÄ+3ùêà)ùêó= ùêÄùêó+3ùêàùêó = (Œª+3ùêà)ùêó$

That means, if ùêÄ plus 3ùêà, then eigenvalues Œª will plus 3ùêà, while eigenvectors doesn’t change.

Can’t generalize

However, th above property (for multiple identity) can’t be generalized to plusing an arbitrary matrix ùêÅ.

Matrix addition doesn’t imply eigenvalues addition, because the eigenvector of ùêÅ is typically not ùêó. Therefore, the following addition can’t be performed:

$$ ùêÄùêó =Œªùêó \\ ùêÅùêó =Œ±ùêó \\ (ùêÄ+ùêÅ)ùêó = (Œª+Œ±)ùêó $$

Complex eigenvalues

Considering rotation matrix:

$$ \begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} cosŒ∏ \\ sinŒ∏ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} cosŒ∏ & -sinŒ∏ \\ sinŒ∏ & cosŒ∏ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned} $$

Let Œ∏ be 90¬∞, the rotation matrix is $[^{0 \ -1}_{1 \ 0}]$.

However, according to the theory “eigenvector outcomes in the direction that it went in”, there seems to be no eigenvector intuitively, as any vector gets in will rotate 90 degree by this matrix.

  1. Solve its eigenvalues:

    $$ \begin{aligned} | ùêÄ - Œªùêà | = 0 \\ |\begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} Œª & 0 \\ 0 & Œª \end{bmatrix}| = \begin{vmatrix} -Œª & -1 \\ 1 & -Œª \end{vmatrix} = 0 \\ Œª^2 + 1 = 0 \end{aligned} $$

    Two roots: Œª‚ÇÅ=i, Œª‚ÇÇ=-i

    Anti-symmetric matrix has imaginary eigenvalues which are always in pairs, as they’re complex conjugate. While a symmetrix matrix’s eigenvalues are all real numbers.

  2. Solve eigenvectors ùêó:

    • For Œª‚ÇÅ=i,

      $$ \begin{aligned} (ùêÄ - Œªùêà) ùêó = 0 \\ \begin{bmatrix} 0-Œª‚ÇÅ & -1 \\ 1 & 0-Œª‚ÇÅ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix} = 0 \\ \begin{bmatrix} -i & -1 \\ 1 & -i \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix} = 0 \\ \end{aligned} $$

      Let the free variable b=1, then $[^a_b] = [^i_1]$

    • For Œª‚ÇÅ= -i,

      $$ \begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} i & -1 \\ 1 & i \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix} = 0 \\ \end{aligned} $$

      Let the free variable b=1, then $[^a_b] = [^{-i}_1]$

Repeated eigenvalues

Eigenvalues of a triangular matrix is obvious: the diagonal, as the determinant is directly factorized.

Source video: Lesson 3: Complex conjugates and dividing complex numbers - Khan Academy

Given a complex number

$$ z = \underset{‚Üë}{2} + \underset{‚Üë}{\underline{3}} i \\ \quad \quad Re(z) \ Im(z) $$

where $2$ is a real number, $3i$ is an imaginary number. The real part of z $Re(z)$ is 2, while the imaginary part of z $Im(z)$ is 3.

Complex conjugate

The complex conjugate of z is

$$ \bar z \text{ or } z^* = 2 - 3i = \overline{2+3i} $$

where the real part Re(z*) remains the same, while the imaginary part Im(z*) has the opposite sign.

This act like mirror reflecting over Real axis.

The sum of a complex number and its complex conjugate is two times of its real part, 2Re(z):

$$ z + \bar z = a + \cancel bi + a - \cancel bi = 2a = 2 Re(z) = 2 Re(\bar z) $$

Graphically, vector addition

The product of a complex number and its complex conjugate is a real number, and it’s equal to the magnitude of the complex number squared:

$$ z ‚ãÖ \bar z = (a+bi) ‚ãÖ (a-bi) = a¬≤ - (bi)¬≤ = a¬≤ + b¬≤ = |z|¬≤ $$

which is useful in the division of comple numbers: multiply the numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator to convert the division to one complex number

For example:

$$ \begin{aligned} & \frac{1+2i}{4-5i} \\ & = \frac{1+2i}{4-5i} ‚ãÖ \frac{4+5i}{4+5i} \\ & = \frac{(1+2i)(4+5i)}{4¬≤-(5i)¬≤} \\ & = \frac{4+5i + 8i-10}{16+25} \\ & = \frac{-6}{41} + \frac{13i}{41} \end{aligned} $$

Factoring sum of squares

We can factor a difference of squares as:

$$ x¬≤ - y¬≤ = (x-y)(x+y) $$

But the sum of squares x¬≤ + y¬≤ cannot be factorized if without considering imaginary unit i.

$$ \begin{aligned} x¬≤ + y¬≤ & = x¬≤ - (-y¬≤) \\ & = x¬≤ - (- 1 y¬≤) \\ & = x¬≤ - (i¬≤ y¬≤) \\ & = x¬≤ - (iy)¬≤ \\ & = (x-iy) (x+iy) \end{aligned} $$

Modulus of complex value

Source page Lesson 5

The absolute value (modulus) of a number is the distance away from zero.

A complex number $3-4i$ plotted on the complex plane:

The absolute value of 3-4i is the hypotenuse of the right triangle.

Based on the Pythagorean theorem, |3-4i|= ‚àö(3¬≤+4¬≤) = 5. (Because distance is positive, so only take the positive square root).

polar & rectangular forms

Source page: Lesson 5

A complex number can be represented in two forms:

  1. Read number + imaginary number: a + bi
  2. Exponential form

Both of them have the same diagram, and just are described in different coordinates:

The two arguments of complex number z can be (r, œÜ) or (a,b)

  • Magnitude: r = |z| = ‚àö(a¬≤+b¬≤)

  • Argument (Polar angle): œÜ = arctan(b/a)

  • a = r‚ãÖcosœÜ

  • b = r‚ãÖsinœÜ

  • z = a+bi = r‚ãÖcosœÜ + r‚ãÖsinœÜi = r(cosœÜ + sinœÜ i) = $r e^{iœÜ}$

    where $cosœÜ + sinœÜ i = e^{iœÜ}$ can be derived by using Taylor series.

Multiplying complex number

Source page Lesson 7

Given z,

  • 3z has the same direction as z, but three times it’s magnitude;

  • -3z is in the opposite direction, and has three times modulus of z

  • -3iz = $1e^{iœÄ} ‚ãÖ 3e^{i‚ãÖœÄ/2} ‚ãÖ re^{iœÜ} = 3r e^{i(œÄ+œÄ/2+œÜ)}$ which turns into the opposite direction then rotates another 90 degrees in counter-clock wise.

    Or this can be derived from the loop of 1 -> i -> -1 -> -i with multiplying i each time.

  • z‚ãÖ(-1-i) : the angle and modulus of $-1-i$ take effect on z separately.

    • The angle of -1-i is 225 degrees (observed from the complex plane), so it will rotate the z by 225 degrees.

    • The magnitude of -1-i is ‚àö2, so z will be scaled by ‚àö2.

    • (I think it as a vector addition: z‚ãÖ(-1-i) = -z-zi,, but there’re too many steps).

Operations in polar form

Source page: Lesson 8

Multiplication

Given: $$ w‚ÇÅ = 3(cos(330¬∞) + i sin(330¬∞)) \\ w‚ÇÇ = 2(cos(120¬∞) + i sin(120¬∞)) $$

What is w‚ÇÅ‚ãÖw‚ÇÇ ?

$3 e^{i‚ãÖ330¬∞} ‚ãÖ 2 e^{i‚ãÖ120¬∞} = 6 e^{i(450¬∞)}$

w‚ÇÅ‚ãÖw‚ÇÇ can be viewed as w‚ÇÅ transforming w‚ÇÇ, i.e., w‚ÇÇ is transformed by multiplying w‚ÇÅ

  1. The modulus of w‚ÇÇ is scaled by the modulus of w‚ÇÅ (2), so |w‚ÇÅ‚ãÖw‚ÇÇ| = 3‚ãÖ2 = 6;

  2. The argument (angle) of w‚ÇÅ is rotated by the argument of w‚ÇÅ (330¬∞), so arg(w‚ÇÅ‚ãÖw‚ÇÇ) = 120¬∞ + 330¬∞ = 450¬∞ = 90¬∞

So w‚ÇÅ‚ãÖw‚ÇÇ = 6 (cos(90¬∞) + i sin(90¬∞)) = 6i

Division

$$ w‚ÇÅ = 8(cos( \frac{4œÄ}{3} ) + i sin( \frac{4œÄ}{3} )) \\ w‚ÇÇ = 2(cos( \frac{7œÄ}{6} ) + i sin( \frac{7œÄ}{6} )) \\ $$

What is $\frac{w‚ÇÅ}{w‚ÇÇ}$ ?

$8e^{ i\frac{4œÄ}{3} } / (2e^{ i\frac{7œÄ}{6} }) = 4 e^{i(œÄ/6)}$

Another way to think about it is that w‚ÇÅ is transformed by w‚ÇÇ:

  1. the modulus of w‚ÇÅ is divided by the modulus of w‚ÇÇ;

  2. the argument of w‚ÇÅ is rotated clock-wise by the argument of w‚ÇÇ.

modulus argument
|w‚ÇÅ|=8 arg(w‚ÇÅ)=4œÄ/3
|w‚ÇÇ|=2 arg(w‚ÇÇ)=7œÄ/6
|w‚ÇÅ/w‚ÇÇ|=4 arg(w‚ÇÅ/w‚ÇÇ) = 4œÄ/3 - 7œÄ/6 = œÄ/6

So $\frac{w‚ÇÅ}{w‚ÇÇ} = 4(cos(œÄ/6) + i sin(œÄ/6)) = 4(‚àö3/2 + i/2)$

Powers of complex number

Consider the complex number $z = -1 + i \sqrt 3$. Find $z^4$ in polar and rectangular form.

  1. Modulus of z is 2, so its modulus is times itself four times: 2‚Å¥ = 16
  2. Argument of z is œÜ = $\rm arctan(\sqrt 3)$=60¬∞=120¬∞, so its angle rotate by 4 times of its argument: œÜx4 = 480¬∞ = 120¬∞

The polar form is $z‚Å¥ = 16 (cos(120¬∞) + i sin(120¬∞))$, so the rectangular form is $z‚Å¥ = 16(1/2 + i ‚àö3/2) = 8 + i8‚àö3 $

Complex number equations

Given equation x¬≥=1, find all of the real and/or complex roots of this equation.

For a real number: $z= 1 = 1 + 0i = 1e^{i0¬∞}$, its argument arg(z) can be 0, 2œÄ, 4œÄ, …, i.e., $1 = e^{i0} = e^{i2œÄ} = e^{i4œÄ} = e^{i6œÄ}$ …

Plug these exponential form into x¬≥=1:

x¬≥=1 x¬≥=$e^{i2œÄ}$ x¬≥=$e^{i4œÄ}$ x¬≥=$e^{i6œÄ}$
cube root x=1 x=$e^{i2œÄ/3}$ x=$e^{i4œÄ/3}$ x=$e^{i6œÄ/3}$
modulus 1 1 1 1
angle 0 2œÄ/3 = 120¬∞ 4œÄ/3 = 240¬∞ 2œÄ
root x‚ÇÅ x‚ÇÇ x‚ÇÉ redundant
a+bi 1 -1/2 + i‚àö3/2 -1/2 - i‚àö3/2 1

Fundamental theorem of Algebra

Source page: Lesson 9

The Fundamental theorem of Algebra: a n-th degree polynomial has n roots.

$P(x) = ax^n + bx^{n-1} + … + K$

Jacobian matrix

Khan Academy

Prerequisite

Matrix is a linear transformation of space by moving the basis vectors to new landing spot.

$$ \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} \rightarrow \begin{bmatrix} 2x + (-3)y \\ 1x+1y \end{bmatrix} $$

  • “linear”: grid lines remain parallel, evenly spaced and straight lines after transformation.

  • Transform

    The two basis vectors $[^1_0]$ and $[^0_1]$ are moved to $[^2_1]$ and $[^{-3}_{1}]$, which are the columns of the matrix.

    $$ \begin{array}{ccc} \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2+0 \\ 1+0 \end{bmatrix} \\ \\ \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0-3 \\ 0+1 \end{bmatrix} \end{array} $$

  • Reconstruct

    The basis vectors $ùê¢ = [i‚ÇÅ,i‚ÇÇ], ùê£ = [j‚ÇÅ,j‚ÇÇ]$ of the new space are completely made up by original basis vectors $[^1_0]$ and $[^0_1]$:

    $$ \begin{array}{ccc} ùê¢ = \begin{bmatrix} i_1 \\ i_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2√ó1 + (-3)√ó0 \\ 1√ó1 + 1√ó0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{matrix} \text{first component}\\ \text{second component}\end{matrix} \\ \\ ùê£ = \begin{bmatrix} j_1 \\ j_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2√ó0 + (-3)√ó1 \\ 1√ó0 + 1√ó1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{matrix} \text{first component}\\ \text{second component}\end{matrix} \end{array} $$

  • Record

    Matrix records synthesising factor for transforming each original basis vector to the new basis vector:

    The first row of the matrix is the combination factors for the original first basis vector to form the first component of the new first basis vector.
    The second row corresponds to the second component of the new first basis vector, by re-combining the original first basis vector. And so forth.

  • Liner Operator

    Matrix operator ùë≥ takes in a vector and spit out a vector.

    Based on the properties of linearity: scaling and adding, i.e.,

    • L(aùêØ) = aL(ùêØ)
    • L(ùêØ+ùê∞) = L(ùêØ) + L(ùê∞)

    Applying the operator on a vector $[^x_y]$ can be represented as:

    $$ \begin{aligned} L(\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}) &= L(x \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + y \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}) \\ &= x L(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}) + y L(\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}) \end{aligned} $$

    Let $[^x_y]$ equals to $[^2_1]$, the result vector should be 2 times of $L([^1_0])$ plus 3 times of $L([^0_1])$, i.e., $[^1_3]$

    That means matrix transforms the space by modifying the original basis vectors. The coordinates of the given vector have no change either in the original space or the new space.

So the transformation can be found by determining the coefficient of the change of each component.

The first column in the transformation matrix is landing spot of the first basis vector (i.e., x axis)

local linearity

Nonlinear function $f([^x_y]) = \rm [^{x+sin(y)}_{y+sin(x)}]$ has local linearity. Therefore, the local linear transformation can be represented by a 2x2 matrix

Jacobian matrix

There are multiple functions and multiple variables. Jacobian records the effects of each variable on each function. Its organization comes down to local linearity, which allows the nonlinear transformation to be represented as a linear transformation.

Jacobian determinant

Jacobian determinant is the factor of the neighbor area around a point scratched or squished by the local “linear transformation”.

Source video: Ê∑±Â∫¶Â≠¶‰π†-ÂïÉËä±‰π¶0103‰º™ÈÄÜÁü©ÈòµÊúÄÂ∞è‰∫å‰πò (2021-07-22) - ÁßëÁ†îÂ∞èÁÅ∞ÁÅ∞

Solve linear regression

For a n-dimensional linear regression problem,

  • There are N input samples: x‚ÇÅ,x‚ÇÇ,…,$x_N$, where each sample is a n-dimension vector x·µ¢‚àà ‚Ñù‚Åø
  • Their corresponding target outputs are: y‚ÇÅ,y‚ÇÇ,…,$y_N$, where each output is a scalar y·µ¢‚àà ‚Ñù

Hence, these data can be represented as a linear system:

$$ \begin{cases} x‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅa‚ÇÅ + x‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇa‚ÇÇ + … + x‚ÇÅ‚Çôa‚Çô = y‚ÇÅ \\ x‚ÇÇ‚ÇÅa‚ÇÅ + x‚ÇÇ‚ÇÇa‚ÇÇ + … + x‚ÇÇ‚Çôa‚Çô = y‚ÇÅ \\ \vdots \\ x_{N1}a‚ÇÅ + x_{N2}a‚ÇÇ + … + x_{Nn}a‚Çô = y_N \\ \end{cases} $$

Further, this system can be represented with matrix and vector:

$$ \begin{bmatrix} x‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ & x‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ & ‚Ä¶ & x‚ÇÅ‚Çô \\ x‚ÇÅ‚ÇÅ & x‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ & ‚Ä¶ & x‚ÇÅ‚Çô \\ ‚ãÆ & ‚ãÆ & ‚ã± & ‚ãÆ \\ x_{N1} & x_{N2} & ‚Ä¶ & x_{Nn} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a‚ÇÅ \\ a‚ÇÇ \\ ‚ãÆ \\ a‚Çô \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} y‚ÇÅ \\ y‚ÇÇ \\ ‚ãÆ \\ y_N \end{bmatrix} $$

The objective of the linear regression is to solve the weights vector: $[ ^{^{a‚ÇÅ}_{a‚ÇÇ}} _{^{\ ‚Åû}_{a‚Çô}} ]$ from the linear equation: $ùêó_{N√ón} ùêö_{n√ó1} = ùêò_{N√ó1}$.

If N=n (the coefficient matrix is a square matrix), and the data matrix $ùêó_{N√ón}$ is a invertible matrix, then there will be ùêö=ùêó‚Åª¬πùêò, such that the weights vector is determined directly.

But in general, the number of samples N is not equal to the number of features n (N ‚â† n), that is ùêó is not invertible and ùêö cannot be represented as ùêó‚Åª¬πùêò.

Shift from ùêó to ùêó·µÄùêó

Therefore, when the ùêö cannot be reached directly, the solution should be as close to the optimal as possible.

That means the objective is to minimize the distance of two vectors:

J=‚Äñùêóùêö-ùêò‚Äñ¬≤ (without constraints)

And the optimal solution is obtained when

‚àÇJ/‚àÇùêö = ùêó·µÄ(ùêóùêö-ùêò) = 0 ‚áí ùêó·µÄùêóùêö = ùêó·µÄùêò.

Now, the previous ùêó is shifted to here ùêó·µÄùêó ‚àà ‚Ñù‚Åø·ïÅ‚Åø, which is a square matrix. And if ùêó·µÄùêó is invertible, then the optimal ùêö can be calculated in one-shot.

Is ùêó·µÄùêó invertible?

An invertible matrix has to satisfy 2 conditions: it’s a square matrix and its rank equals to the number of variables n (#columns).

According to this video, there are two cases:

  1. If N > n, for example N=5, n=3, then (ùêó·µÄùêó)‚ÇÉ‚Çì‚ÇÉ is inverible generally. So

    ùêö=(ùêó·µÄùêó)‚Åª¬πùêó·µÄùêò,

    where the coefficient in front of ùêò, (ùêó·µÄùêó)‚Åª¬πùêó·µÄ, is called the pseudo-inverse matrix. And ùêö = (ùêó·µÄùêó)‚Åª¬πùêó·µÄùêò is called the least-square solution. (ÊúÄÂ∞è‰∫å‰πòËß£)

    (Because ùêó has no inverse matrix, so we find its “pseudo” inverse matrix. Or if ùêó is invertible, ùêó‚Åª¬π=(ùêó·µÄùêó)‚Åª¬πùêó·µÄ, they’re equivalent, but the latter suits more general scenarios.).

  2. If N < n, for example N=3, n=5, then (ùêó·µÄùêó)‚ÇÖ‚Çì‚ÇÖ is not invertible, because:
    rank(ùêó·µÄùêó) ‚â§ rank(ùêó‚ÇÉ‚Çì‚ÇÖ) ‚â§ N=3 < n=5.

    In this case, ùêö cannot be calculated as (ùêó·µÄùêó)‚Åª¬πùêó·µÄùêò.

The problem can be understood that there are too many parameters (n is too high). When the parameters are much more than samples, there will be overfitting. And one of the solutions is regularization.

Effect of the regularization term

Since the reason why the optimal solution of the loss function J cannot be solved in one-shot is that the there are too many parameters, a regularization is added to the loss funciton as follows:

$$J = ‚Äñùêóùêö-ùêò‚Äñ¬≤ + Œª‚Äñùêö‚Äñ¬≤, Œª>0$$

Then the derivative becomes:

‚àÇJ/‚àÇùêö = ùêó·µÄùêóùêö - ùêó·µÄùêò + Œªùêö = 0.

By moving items, the equation becomes:

(ùêó·µÄùêó + Œªùêà)ùêö = ùêó·µÄùêò,

where the (ùêó·µÄùêó + Œªùêà) is invertible. The proof is as follows.

Proof

Since ùêó·µÄùêó is a symmetric matrix, it can be diagonalized. Thus, ùêó·µÄùêó can be written as:

$$ ùêó·µÄùêó = ùêè‚Åª¬π \begin{bmatrix} Œª‚ÇÅ & & \\ & ‚ã± & \\ & & Œª‚Çô \end{bmatrix} ùêè $$

The determinant of ùêó·µÄùêó is:
|ùêó·µÄùêó| = |ùêè‚Åª¬π| ‚ãÖ |$^{^{Œª‚ÇÅ}_{\quad ‚ã±}} _{\qquad Œª‚Çô}$| ‚ãÖ |ùêè| = Œª‚ÇÅ ‚ãÖ Œª‚ÇÇ ‚Ä¶ ‚ãÖ Œª‚Çô

And Œª‚ÇÅ, Œª‚ÇÇ ‚Ä¶, Œª‚Çô are the eigen values for the ùêó·µÄùêó

Then the invertibility can be judged from this determinant:

  • If |ùêó·µÄùêó| = 0, then ùêó·µÄùêó is not invertible, because there are some zero lines in the matrix (after elementary row operations), that means r(ùêó·µÄùêó) < n.
  • But if |ùêó·µÄùêó| > 0, the matrix ùêó·µÄùêó is invertible, because it has full rank, which is equal to the number of lines of rows. ¬≤

Analyze the two cases without and with adding the regularization term:

  1. Only the ùêó·µÄùêó:

    • Let this matrix be enclosed by a non-zero real row vector ùõÇ·µÄ and its column vector ùõÇ to constuct a quadratic form: ùõÇ·µÄ(ùêó·µÄùêó)ùõÇ, which is used to characterize the definiteness of ùêó·µÄùêó. ¬≥
    • Based on the combination law of the matrix multiplication, it can be written as: (ùõÇ·µÄùêó·µÄ)(ùêóùõÇ) = (ùêóùõÇ)·µÄ(ùêóùõÇ), which is the norm of the vector ùêóùõÇ.
    • Because the norm is ‚â• 0 definitely, the ùõÇ·µÄ(ùêó·µÄùêó)ùõÇ ‚â• 0 (indicating ùêó·µÄùêó is positive semi-definite matrix).
    • Based on the properties of quadratic form, eigen values Œª·µ¢ of ùêó·µÄùêó are all ‚â• 0

(2023-10-17)

Absorb BN

  1. Normalization is performed to keep each “stage” (layer) in a network maintain the same distribution, such that the training could be more efficient due to

    1. Leaving out modeling distributions shift of each layer’s input data.

    2. Stabilizing optimization by suppressing “outliers” (high value) in the output feature map of each layer to avoid big variations in the final prediction.

      Refer to: BN„ÄÅBNÂêåÊ≠•„ÄÅÂê∏Êî∂BN - EveKÁöÑÊñáÁ´† - Áü•‰πé

  2. Specifically, input data has (mean=0, std=1), but after a conv layer, the outcome feature maps may don’t persist (mean=0, std=1).

    1. Ideally, featue maps’s distribution should be transformed to (mean=0, std=1) to align with the input data. And that transformation requires its whitening matrix , which transforms co-variance matrix of the feature maps an identity matrix, meaning each dimension is unrelated. CSDN

      However, solving the whitening matrix for a high-dimension tensor is time consuming.

      Therefore, the “whitening” is performed only for each channel.

    2. On the other hand, it’s difficult to get the exact distributions at once, because the data is trained batch-by-batch.

      Therefore, the distribution to be corrected pertains only to the small batch of data. (Or involving previous data by using moving average of history mean and std)

      And only 2 parameters (mean, std) of their distribution are considered to keep the distributions consistent.

  3. Once a feature map $M_{(N, C, H, W)}$ spit out from a conv layer, BatchNorm normalizes the data at the same channel for all N samples in the batch:

    \begin{algorithm}
\begin{algorithmic}
\FOR {i=0 \TO M.size(1)}
  \PROCEDURE{BN}{ M, mean ∞, std ∞, scale, bias}
    \STATE mean = M[:, i, :, :].sum() / N   

    \STATE std = ( (M[:, i, :, :] - mean)¬≤ / N ).sqrt()

    \STATE M‚Å∞¬π = (M[:, i, :, :] - mean) / std

    \STATE M' = scale * M‚Å∞¬π + bias
  \ENDPROCEDURE
\ENDFOR
\end{algorithmic}
\end{algorithm}

    • mean ∞ and std ∞ are from history.

    • The scale factor Œ≥ and bias Œ≤ are for the situation where the variation is very small. Then the differences can be magnified through scaling to avoid representation capacity degradation.

    • And Œ≥,Œ≤ are required to be learnable to automatically find the appropriate feature levels. Otherwise, bias will grow to infinity as explained in paper.

  4. Combine BN into wights and bias of the last layer

    $$ M’ = Œ≥ \frac{M - mean}{std} + Œ≤ = \frac{Œ≥‚ãÖM}{std} \left( Œ≤ - \frac{Œ≥ ‚ãÖ mean}{std} \right) $$

    If M is calculated as $M = w‚ãÖx + b$, by substituting it, the equation becomes:

    $$ M’= \frac{Œ≥‚ãÖw}{std} x + \left( Œ≤ - \frac{Œ≥‚ãÖmean}{std} + \frac{Œ≥‚ãÖb}{std} \right) $$

    Thus, w becomes $\frac{Œ≥‚ãÖw}{std}$ and b becomes $( Œ≤ - \frac{Œ≥‚ãÖmean}{std} + \frac{Œ≥‚ãÖb}{std} )$.

  5. Given a conv layer with $C_i$ input channels and $C_o$ output channels, BN for this layer has $C_i √ó C_o$ parameters, where $C_i$ is for the history channels, $C_o$ is for target channels.

item.title: memo: DL | Weight initialization
item.description:
The maximum gradient of the sigmoid activation function is 0.25, which may cause partial derivative of loss with respect to the earlier weight w very small after passing throught multipler layers. And scaling the weights down can mitigate the gradient decrease.

Based on the chain rule, the derivative of the weight in the fisrt layer (l=1) is ‚àÇloss/‚àÇw¬π = ‚àÇloss/‚àÇo ‚ãÖ ‚àÇo/‚àÇa¬≤ ‚ãÖ ‚àÇa¬≤/‚àÇa¬π ‚ãÖ ‚àÇa¬π/‚àÇw¬π, where a = g(z), g is an activation function.

If the weight w¬π is small, the activation z¬π is small (around zero), so ‚àÇa¬π/‚àÇz¬π corresponds to the highest derivative. And also if w¬≤ is small, ‚àÇa¬≤/‚àÇa¬π = ‚àÇa¬≤/‚àÇz¬≤‚ãÖ ‚àÇz¬≤/‚àÇa¬π, where ‚àÇa¬≤/‚àÇz¬≤ will be a big derivative. Hence, ‚àÇloss/‚àÇw¬π can maintain a high derivative.

So it’s importance to initialize the weights centered at zero with small variance for getting the maximum gradient. L11.5 Weight Initialization – Why Do We Care?

Activation z is a sum of w·µ¢x·µ¢, so it may be exploding or vanishing quickly if the W doesn’t have constriant. Weight Initialization in a Deep Network (C2W1L11) - Andrew Ng

Depthwise Convolution

date: 2023-07-25

Separate a convolution into two steps:

  1. Shrink the size of the feature maps using 1-channel plane-wise kernel (Depthwise Conv);

  2. Expand the number of channels using 1x1 kernel (Pointwise Conv).
